column1: Immokalee () is an unincorporated community and census-designated place in Collier County
The region was occupied by the Calusa Indians and centuries later occupied by the Seminole
column2: after they moved down from the northern part of Florida. Initially the settlement was known as Gopher Ridge by the Seminole and Miccosukee Indians. Immokalee means "your home" in the Mikasuki language.When the swamps were drained in the region
column3: agriculture became the dominant industry. European-American hunters
column7: and missionaries moved in before the development of permanent villages. The first permanent settlement was founded in 1872. In 1921
column8: the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad extended its Haines City Branch south to Immokalee.  The railroad was removed in the late 1980s.The Immokalee area is heavily agricultural. It is one of the major centers of tomato growing in the United States. In 1960
column9: CBS News anchor Edward R. Murrow reported on the working conditions in the surrounding farms for his Harvest of Shame report for CBS Reports
column10: which described the harsh lives of migrant workers.

column1: Immokalee is located in northern Collier County along Florida State Road 29. LaBelle is 24 miles (39 km) to the north
column2: and Interstate 75 (Alligator Alley) is 20 miles (32 km) to the south.

column2: the area has no municipal government of its own and is governed by Collier County

column1: Immokalee's public schools are operated by the District School Board of Collier County.
Elementary schools in Immokalee and serving Immokalee include Eden Park
column4: and Village Oaks. Pinecrest Elementary School
column5: located outside of and adjacent to the CDP
column6: serves a portion of the CDP. All residents are zoned to Immokalee Middle School and Immokalee High School

column1: Immokalee Airport is a public-use airport located 1 mile (1.6 km) northeast of the central business district.
Collier Area Transit provides the local bus service and paratransit. The #5 connects to Naples
column2: the #7 connects to Marco Island (limited trips)
column3: and the 8A circulates within the area.

column1: Immokalee used to be served by the Seaboard Coast Line Railroad (formerly Atlantic Coast Line) which ran a branchline from Palmdale through Immokalee to Everglades City. The line used to generate considerable agricultural-related traffic. The rail line was cut back to Sunniland south of Immokalee in the 1950s and then abandoned to the mainline at Palmdale in the 1980s.  This left Immokalee without rail service.
The main road through Immokalee is State Road 29. Other important county roads through the region are CR 29A and CR 846.
The federally recognized Seminole Tribe of Florida has one of its six reservations here
column3: on which it operates one of its gaming casinos.

column1: The Audubon Society's Corkscrew Swamp Sanctuary is nearby.

column2: a low power community radio station owned and operated by the Coalition of Immokalee Workers. The station was built by numerous volunteers from Immokalee and around the country in December 2003 at the fifth Prometheus Radio Project barnraising. WCIW broadcasts music
column4: and public affairs to listeners in Spanish
column5: Haitian Creole and several indigenous languages.

column1: WAFZ-FM (92.1 FM) is a full-power FM radio station licensed to Immokalee
column2: Florida. The station plays a variety of new and current hits in the Regional Mexican format. In the 1980s
column3: WAFZ also played Tejano music on its sister station WAFZ-AM. In its beginnings WAFZ had been WZOR-AM 1490 and English programming adult contemporary music and news in the morning and until 3pm. Then it changed its format to Regional Mexican/Tejano. The early DJs that worked there were Gabino Soliz
column5: and Irma Ayala. The station continued on the air for a long time until the mid-1990s
column6: when it went silent for a while until what is now WAFZ was bought by Glades Media Company LLC
column7: and transmitted simultaneously what WAFZ-FM was playing (a regional Mexican format). The current format of WAFZ is a young Regional Mexican
column8: playing newer top 40 hits of the genre.

column1: WAFZ's programming is also heard on WAFZ AM 1490 in Immokalee.
